rm_dangerous.explanation: This 'rm -rf' command targets critical system locations!
rm_dangerous.consequence: Could delete root (/), home (~), current dir (*), or variables.
advice: Use 'rm -i' for interactive confirmation
Always specify exact file/folder names
Use 'trash-cli' instead of rm for safety

chmod_777.explanation: chmod 777 gives EVERYONE full access to your files.
chmod_777.consequence: This is a major security risk!
advice: Use specific permissions like 'chmod 755' or 'chmod 644'
Only give write access when necessary

chmod_000.explanation: chmod 000 removes ALL permissions - nobody can access the file!
chmod_000.consequence: You won't be able to read, write, or execute the file. Even you!
advice: Use 'chmod 644' for regular files (read/write for you, read for others)
Use 'chmod 755' for executables
chmod 000 makes files completely inaccessible

dd_zero.explanation: The command 'dd if=/dev/zero' can destroy disk data.
dd_zero.consequence: It can cause irreversible data loss.
advice: Always backup before destructive operations
Test commands in a safe environment first

drop_database.explanation: DROP DATABASE permanently deletes an entire database.
drop_database.consequence: It can cause irreversible data loss.
advice: Always backup before destructive operations
Test commands in a safe environment first

fork_bomb.explanation: This is a FORK BOMB - a DOS attack that freezes your system!
fork_bomb.consequence: Your system will become unresponsive and require reboot.
advice: Never run code you don't understand
This is a malicious command, not a mistake

redirect_to_disk.explanation: /dev/sda is your PHYSICAL DISK, not a file! Redirecting output here writes directly to the disk hardware, destroying the boot sector and partition table.
redirect_to_disk.consequence: All data on the disk will be lost. Your system won't boot. Recovery is nearly impossible.
advice: NEVER redirect to /dev/sd* devices (these are physical disks)
/dev/sda = entire first disk, /dev/sdb = second disk, etc.
Use regular files for output: > /tmp/output.txt

mkfs_disk.explanation: mkfs formats the disk, erasing EVERYTHING on it!
mkfs_disk.consequence: All data on the disk will be permanently lost.
advice: Always verify the device name before formatting
Use 'lsblk' to check disk layout first

mv_to_null.explanation: Moving files to /dev/null makes them disappear forever!
mv_to_null.consequence: Files sent to /dev/null cannot be recovered.
advice: Use 'rm' if you want to delete (at least it's explicit)
Consider using a trash utility instead

overwrite_file.explanation: Redirecting nothing to a file overwrites it with 0 bytes!
overwrite_file.consequence: The file will be empty - all content lost.
advice: Use 'echo "" > file' if you want to clear a file
Better yet, use a text editor to modify files

dd_random.explanation: This command fills your disk with random data!
dd_random.consequence: All data will be overwritten and unrecoverable.
advice: Only use dd for legitimate disk operations
Always triple-check the 'of=' parameter

kernel_panic.explanation: /proc/sysrq-trigger is a KERNEL CONTROL interface! Writing 'c' here forces an immediate kernel panic (crash). This is like pressing the emergency stop button on your system.
kernel_panic.consequence: Instant system crash. All unsaved work lost. Requires hard reboot. Potential filesystem corruption.
advice: NEVER write to /proc/sysrq-trigger in normal operation
/proc/ contains kernel interfaces, not regular files
This is only for kernel debugging by experts

shred_secure.explanation: shred overwrites files multiple times to make recovery IMPOSSIBLE! When used on disk devices (/dev/sda) or with high iteration counts, it destroys data permanently.
shred_secure.consequence: Data cannot be recovered. Unlike 'rm', shred makes files truly unrecoverable. On disk devices, it destroys everything.
advice: NEVER use shred on /dev/sd* devices (entire disk destruction)
Verify the file path THREE times before running shred
Use 'rm' for normal deletion - shred is for secure deletion only
High iteration counts (-n 100) take very long and are usually unnecessary

system_modify.explanation: Modifying critical system files (/etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, /etc/fstab, /boot) or writing to /dev/mem can CORRUPT your entire system!
system_modify.consequence: System becomes unbootable, users locked out, or complete system instability. Recovery requires rescue mode or reinstallation.
advice: NEVER directly edit /etc/passwd or /etc/shadow - use 'useradd', 'usermod', 'passwd' commands
NEVER delete /etc or /boot directories
NEVER write to /dev/mem - this is raw memory access
Use proper system administration tools instead of direct file manipulation
